The morning sun cast long shadows across the Ponsonby terrace house as twelve-year-old Marcus Chen pressed his nose against the rain-streaked window of his bedroom. Below in the narrow garden, old Hamish McGregor was already at work among the winter vegetables, his weathered hands coaxing life from the Auckland clay despite the persistent drizzle that seemed to define this particular July. Marcus watched the elderly Scotsman's methodical movements with fascination, noting how he treated each plant as if it were a delicate treasure rather than mere greenery.

"Marcus! Breakfast!" His mother's voice carried up the stairs with that familiar note of impatience that had become increasingly common since his father's promotion had begun requiring longer hours at the engineering firm. Dr. Sarah Chen had her own demanding schedule at Auckland Hospital, and the morning routine had become a carefully orchestrated dance of efficiency that left little room for dawdling.

As Marcus reluctantly pulled himself away from the window, his gaze fell upon the stack of tissue paper he'd carefully hidden beneath his school books. The vibrant sheets of crimson, gold, and emerald green seemed to pulse with possibility in the dim morning light. Yesterday, during what was supposed to be a productive study session at the Central Library, he'd discovered something that had ignited a spark of creativity he'd never known existed within him.

It had happened quite by accident. While searching for a book on New Zealand history for his upcoming project, Marcus had wandered into the craft section and stumbled upon an elderly Chinese woman teaching a small group of children how to create elaborate flowers from simple tissue paper. Her fingers moved with an almost magical precision, folding and twisting the delicate material until it bloomed into roses that looked almost real enough to carry fragrance.

"Mei-Mei used to make these for Chinese New Year when she was young girl in Guangzhou," the woman had explained in careful English, her eyes twinkling as she noticed Marcus hovering nearby. "Is very old tradition. Each flower carries wishes for prosperity and happiness."

Something about the gentle concentration required for the craft had called to Marcus in a way that rugby practice and cricket matches never had. When Mrs. Liu – as she'd introduced herself – had invited him to join the group, he'd felt an unfamiliar sense of belonging. His usually clumsy fingers had seemed to understand the delicate work instinctively, and by the end of the session, he'd created a passable lotus blossom that Mrs. Liu had praised with genuine enthusiasm.

"You have gift," she'd told him quietly as the other children packed up their materials. "Most boys, they too rough with paper. But you understand gentleness. This is rare thing."

Now, as Marcus descended the stairs toward the inevitable rush of morning preparations, he clutched the memory of those words like a talisman. The tissue paper upstairs represented something he couldn't quite articulate – a doorway to a part of himself that felt both foreign and completely natural.

The kitchen was already bustling with controlled chaos when he arrived. His mother stood at the counter, efficiently packing lunches while simultaneously reviewing patient notes on her tablet. His father, David, sat hunched over his laptop, a piece of toast growing cold beside him as he frowned at what appeared to be architectural blueprints on the screen.

"Morning, mate," his father mumbled without looking up. "Don't forget you've got rugby training after school today. Coach Morrison says the team needs to work on their scrummage technique before Saturday's match."

Marcus felt his stomach tighten at the reminder. Rugby had been his father's passion during his own school years, and David Chen had naturally assumed his son would share the same enthusiasm for the sport. The reality was far different – Marcus found the aggressive physicality and constant shouting more exhausting than exhilarating, and he'd spent most practices hoping to remain invisible enough to avoid being selected for actual gameplay.

"Actually, Dad, I was thinking maybe I could skip training today. I have that history project due next week, and I really need to get started on the research."

Dr. Chen glanced up from her tablet with a slight frown. "Marcus, you know how we feel about commitment. You made a promise to your team when you joined, and following through on obligations is important for character development."

"Besides," his father added, finally looking away from his screen, "fresh air and physical exercise are exactly what you need. All this indoor time isn't healthy for a boy your age. When I was twelve, I was outside every moment I wasn't in school or sleeping."

Marcus nodded dutifully while internally calculating how he might manage to visit Mrs. Liu's craft session again without arousing suspicion. The group met every Tuesday and Thursday afternoon, which unfortunately coincided perfectly with his rugby commitments. Perhaps he could claim to need extra tutoring in mathematics – his grades in that subject were genuinely struggling enough to make the excuse plausible.

"Hamish seems to be making good progress with the winter plantings," Marcus offered, hoping to change the subject while moving toward a topic that genuinely interested him. "I was watching him work this morning, and he's got those broad beans looking really healthy despite all the rain we've been having."

His mother smiled briefly. "Yes, we're fortunate to have him. Finding someone with his knowledge and dedication isn't easy these days. Most young people aren't interested in that kind of patient, detailed work anymore."

The irony of her words wasn't lost on Marcus, though he kept his expression neutral. If only she knew about the patient, detailed work that had captured his imagination so completely just yesterday. But something told him that tissue paper flowers wouldn't be met with the same approval as successful vegetable gardens or rugby achievements.

As breakfast concluded with the usual flurry of grabbed bags, quick kisses, and reminders about after-school activities, Marcus found himself walking toward Ponsonby Intermediate with a growing sense of internal division. On the surface, he was the dutiful son of successful professional parents, expected to excel academically while maintaining appropriate masculine interests in competitive sports. But beneath that carefully maintained exterior, something new was stirring – a creative impulse that felt both exciting and dangerous.

The school day passed in its typical blur of mathematics struggles, English compositions, and social studies discussions about early Maori settlements. Marcus found his attention wandering repeatedly to memories of Mrs. Liu's gentle instructions and the surprising satisfaction he'd felt when the tissue paper had responded to his careful manipulations. During lunch break, instead of joining his usual group for an improvised game of touch rugby, he retreated to the library and spent the time sketching flower designs in the margins of his notebook.

"Watcha drawing there, Chen?" The voice belonged to Jake Morrison, the rugby coach's son and one of the more vocal members of Marcus's year group. Jake had inherited his father's broad shoulders and aggressive confidence, along with an unfortunate tendency to view any activity that didn't involve physical competition with suspicion.

Marcus quickly closed his notebook, but not before Jake caught a glimpse of the delicate petals he'd been sketching. "Just some diagrams for science class. We're studying plant biology."

"Looked more like girly flower pictures to me," Jake said with a smirk that attracted the attention of several nearby students. "What's next, Chen? Gonna start writing love poems and painting your nails?"

The laughter that followed Jake's comment felt like a physical blow to Marcus's chest. He forced himself to maintain a neutral expression while internally cursing his carelessness. This was exactly the kind of reaction he'd feared, and it confirmed his instinct that his newfound interest needed to remain secret.

"Don't be ridiculous," Marcus replied with what he hoped sounded like casual dismissal. "I was just doodling while thinking about Coach Morrison's scrummage drills. Sometimes drawing helps me visualize the plays better."

Jake seemed satisfied with this explanation, and the conversation moved on to speculation about Saturday's upcoming match against their traditional rivals from Remuera. But Marcus spent the remainder of lunch period acutely aware of how quickly his private world could be exposed and ridiculed.As the afternoon wore on, Marcus found himself increasingly preoccupied with the collision between his public obligations and private desires. During social studies, while Mr. Patterson droned on about the Treaty of Waitangi, Marcus's mind wandered to the intricate folding techniques Mrs. Liu had demonstrated. He remembered how she had explained that each crease carried meaning, that the ancient art of paper folding was considered a form of meditation in Chinese culture. The idea that creativity could be a spiritual practice was entirely foreign to his experience, yet it resonated with something deep inside him that he couldn't quite name.

When the final bell rang, Marcus gathered his books with unusual reluctance. The prospect of rugby training felt more burdensome than ever, particularly after Jake's earlier comments had made him hyperaware of how his teammates might perceive any deviation from expected masculine behavior. He trudged toward the changing rooms with the grim determination of a soldier heading into an unwelcome battle, already mentally preparing himself for two hours of physical discomfort and forced enthusiasm.

The familiar smell of liniment and sweaty uniforms greeted him as he entered the changing room, where his teammates were already engaged in their pre-training ritual of boastful conversation and aggressive humor. Marcus changed into his practice gear quietly, hoping to avoid drawing attention to himself, but Coach Morrison had other plans.

"Right then, lads!" the coach's voice boomed across the room with characteristic intensity. "Today we're focusing on pack coordination and driving power. Chen, you'll be starting at hooker today. Johnson's still nursing that ankle injury, so I need you to step up and show some leadership in the front row."

Marcus felt his heart sink at this announcement. Playing hooker meant being directly in the middle of every scrum, responsible for accurately throwing the ball into lineouts, and generally being far more involved in the game's physical confrontations than he preferred. It was exactly the kind of prominent role he'd spent months trying to avoid, and now he was being thrust into it at a time when his confidence was already shaken.

"Yes, sir," he managed to reply with what he hoped sounded like appropriate enthusiasm, though several of his teammates exchanged glances that suggested his lack of genuine excitement hadn't gone unnoticed.

The training session that followed was every bit as challenging as Marcus had feared. His lineout throws were consistently inaccurate, sailing either too high for the jumping forwards to reach or falling short of their intended targets. During scrummage practice, he found himself repeatedly overwhelmed by the opposing pack's driving force, unable to maintain the steady platform that his teammates needed. Coach Morrison's increasingly frustrated instructions seemed to make matters worse rather than better, and Marcus could feel his confidence eroding with each failed attempt.

"Chen, you're thinking too much out there!" the coach barked after a particularly disastrous scrum collapse. "Rugby isn't played in your head, son. It's about instinct and aggression. You need to trust your body and stop being so bloody tentative about everything!"

The irony of this advice wasn't lost on Marcus. His recent experience with tissue paper flowers had taught him that some of the most satisfying work required exactly the kind of careful thought and gentle precision that Coach Morrison was telling him to abandon. The contrast between the two activities couldn't have been more stark – one demanded violent forward momentum and dominating physicality, while the other rewarded patient observation and delicate manipulation. He was beginning to understand that his natural temperament was far better suited to the latter, but saying so would have been unthinkable in his current environment.

As practice finally drew to a close, Marcus felt emotionally and physically drained in a way that had nothing to do with healthy exhaustion. He changed back into his school uniform mechanically, barely participating in the post-training analysis that his teammates seemed to relish. When Jake Morrison approached him near the school gates, Marcus braced himself for another uncomfortable conversation.

"Rough session today, mate," Jake said, though his tone carried more curiosity than malice. "You seemed pretty distracted out there. Everything alright at home?"

The question caught Marcus off guard with its unexpected note of genuine concern. Jake might be loud and sometimes insensitive, but he wasn't deliberately cruel, and his father's position as coach meant he had a better understanding than most of the pressures that came with team sports. For a moment, Marcus considered whether he might be able to confide in someone about his conflicted feelings, but the memory of lunchtime's mocking laughter quickly dismissed that possibility.

"Just having trouble concentrating lately," Marcus replied carefully. "Maybe I need to get my eyes checked or something. The ball kept looking blurry during lineout practice."

Jake nodded with apparent understanding. "Yeah, that happened to me last year. Turns out I needed glasses for distance vision. Made a huge difference once I got them sorted. You should definitely talk to your parents about seeing an optometrist."

As they parted ways at the bus stop, Marcus reflected on how easy it had become to construct small deceptions to explain away his struggles. The lie about blurry vision was entirely fabricated, but it provided a convenient medical explanation for his poor performance that didn't require him to examine the deeper truth about his fundamental lack of enthusiasm for rugby. He was becoming skilled at building protective barriers between his inner reality and external expectations, though he wasn't sure whether this was a valuable life skill or a troubling character flaw.

The bus ride home gave him time to decompress from the afternoon's frustrations while planning his next move regarding the tissue paper flowers. Mrs. Liu had mentioned that her craft group met twice weekly, and he was determined to find a way to attend at least one more session. The challenge would be creating a plausible excuse that wouldn't raise suspicions about his true activities. Perhaps he could claim to have joined a study group that met at the library, or volunteer for some kind of community service project that required regular afternoon commitments.# Chapter 2

The following Tuesday morning arrived with the kind of crisp winter clarity that made Auckland's harbor sparkle like scattered diamonds in the distance. Marcus had spent the better part of three days crafting what he believed to be the perfect excuse for missing rugby training, a story involving voluntary tutoring sessions for younger students who were struggling with their mathematics. The lie sat uncomfortably in his stomach like a cold stone, but his desperate desire to return to Mrs. Liu's craft group had overridden his usual reluctance to deceive his parents.

"That's very commendable, Marcus," his mother had said when he'd presented his fabricated community service commitment over breakfast. "Helping younger students develop confidence in mathematics will be excellent experience for you, and it shows real maturity to recognize that your own understanding improves when you teach others." Dr. Chen had looked genuinely pleased by what she perceived as her son's growing social responsibility, which only intensified Marcus's guilt about the deception.

His father had been equally supportive, though with characteristic pragmatism. "Just make sure you're not taking on so much extra responsibility that your own grades suffer," David had cautioned while reviewing his morning emails. "And don't forget that rugby training is still your primary after-school commitment. This tutoring thing is admirable, but it can't become a regular excuse to avoid team responsibilities."

Now, as Marcus sat through morning classes with unusual attentiveness, he found himself simultaneously excited about the afternoon's prospects and anxious about the increasingly complex web of lies he was constructing. During interval break, he'd already had to deflect questions from Jake Morrison about why he wouldn't be at training, and he suspected that his evasive answers had only increased his teammate's curiosity about his recent behavioral changes.

The mathematics class that immediately preceded lunch proved to be particularly challenging, as Mr. Henderson decided to focus on geometric principles that required exactly the kind of spatial reasoning that Marcus found most difficult. While his classmates worked through problems involving angle calculations and area measurements, Marcus struggled with concepts that seemed to shift and blur whenever he tried to pin them down logically. The irony that he was supposedly tutoring other students in this very subject made his genuine confusion feel even more frustrating.

"Marcus, would you like to demonstrate the solution to problem number seven for the class?" Mr. Henderson's invitation carried the tone of someone who had noticed his student's wandering attention and decided to refocus it through direct engagement.

Marcus approached the whiteboard with considerable reluctance, acutely aware that his classmates were watching his every move. The problem involved calculating the area of an irregular polygon, which required breaking the shape down into manageable triangular components before applying the appropriate formulas. As he stared at the diagram, Marcus felt the familiar sensation of mathematical concepts slipping away from his grasp like water through cupped fingers.

"Take your time," Mr. Henderson encouraged, though Marcus could detect a note of growing impatience in the teacher's voice. "Remember that complex problems become much more manageable when you break them down into smaller, familiar components."

The advice was sound in theory, but Marcus found himself unable to visualize how the irregular shape might be subdivided effectively. His hand hovered uncertainly over the whiteboard marker while thirty pairs of eyes waited for him to demonstrate competence he simply didn't possess. The silence stretched uncomfortably until Sarah Kim, one of the class's most mathematically gifted students, raised her hand and offered to help work through the problem step by step.

"Thank you, Sarah," Mr. Henderson said with obvious relief. "Marcus, please pay close attention to Sarah's approach. I think you'll find her methodology quite instructive."

As Marcus returned to his seat with burning cheeks and wounded pride, he couldn't help but reflect on the contrast between his mathematical struggles and his apparent natural aptitude for delicate handwork. Yesterday evening, in the privacy of his bedroom, he had successfully recreated one of Mrs. Liu's tissue paper roses using only his imperfect memory of her techniques. The flower that emerged from his careful folding and twisting had possessed an organic beauty that filled him with quiet satisfaction, yet this creative achievement meant nothing in the context of his academic requirements or social expectations.

The remainder of the school day passed with agonizing slowness as Marcus's anticipation for the afternoon craft session grew steadily stronger. During English literature class, while Mrs. Patterson led a discussion about character development in the novel they were studying, Marcus found his attention drifting to speculation about what new techniques Mrs. Liu might teach today. He imagined learning to create more complex flowers, perhaps the elaborate chrysanthemums he had seen in Chinese restaurants, or delicate cherry blossoms that captured the essence of spring despite the current winter weather.

When the final bell finally rang at three-fifteen, Marcus gathered his books with unusual efficiency and headed directly for the school gates, avoiding the usual post-class socializing that might have led to awkward questions about his afternoon plans. The walk to the Central Library took nearly twenty minutes, but he used the time to mentally rehearse explanations for his prolonged absence from rugby training, hoping that consistent repetition might make his fabricated tutoring story feel more natural and believable.

The library's familiar atmosphere of hushed concentration and scholarly purpose greeted him as he entered through the heavy glass doors. Marcus made his way toward the children's section where Mrs. Liu held her craft sessions, his heart beating faster with each step. Part of him worried that she might not remember him from the previous week, or that the group might be full of regular participants who would view him as an unwelcome intruder in their established community.

His concerns proved groundless as he rounded the corner and spotted Mrs. Liu arranging supplies at a large circular table. She looked up at his approach with a genuine smile of recognition that immediately put him at ease, her weathered face creasing with apparent pleasure at seeing him again.

"Ah, Marcus! I was hoping you might return today. I brought some special papers from home that I thought you might enjoy working with." Mrs. Liu gestured toward a collection of tissue papers in colors he had never seen before – subtle lavenders and deep burgundies, soft peach tones and rich emerald greens that seemed to shimmer with their own inner light. "These colors are traditional for autumn flowers in Chinese culture. Very appropriate for your Auckland winter, I think."

As other participants began arriving for the session, Marcus found himself welcomed into the group with easy acceptance that contrasted sharply with his recent experiences in rugby training. The other children – mostly girls ranging in age from about eight to fourteen – seemed genuinely interested in sharing techniques and admiring each other's work rather than competing for dominance or status. The atmosphere felt collaborative and supportive in a way that was entirely foreign to his usual after-school activities.

"Today we learn to make peony flowers," Mrs. Liu announced once everyone had settled around the table. "Peony is very special flower in Chinese tradition. Symbol of honor and wealth, but also represents feminine beauty and delicate strength. Is flower that appears soft and gentle, but actually very hardy and long-lasting."

As Mrs. Liu began demonstrating the initial folding techniques, Marcus found himself completely absorbed in the intricate process. Creating a peony required a more complex series of cuts and folds than the simple roses he had attempted previously, demanding both careful attention to detail and a willingness to work with the natural properties of the tissue paper rather than fighting against them. The process reminded him of what he had observed in Hamish McGregor's gardening work – a patient collaboration between human intention and natural materials that produced results far more beautiful than either could achieve alone.

"Very good, Marcus!" Mrs. Liu's praise came as he successfully completed his first attempt at the challenging flower. "You see how paper wants to curl naturally at edges? Most people try to force flat shape, but you understand to work with natural tendency. This shows wisdom."

The compliment filled Marcus with a warmth that was entirely different from the grudging acknowledgment he occasionally received for rugby efforts or academic achievements. Mrs. Liu's approval seemed to recognize something essentially valuable about his approach to the work, rather than simply measuring his performance against external standards. For perhaps the first time in his twelve years, Marcus felt genuinely seen and appreciated for qualities that came naturally to him rather than skills he was expected to develop through discipline and effort.

As the session continued, Marcus found himself drawn into conversations with his fellow participants that revealed perspectives on creativity and personal expression he had never encountered before. Emma, a thirteen-year-old with paint-stained fingers and an infectious enthusiasm for art projects, described how she used craft activities as a way to process difficult emotions and work through problems that seemed unsolvable through logical thinking alone.

"Sometimes when I'm really upset about something, I can't figure out what I'm feeling or why," Emma explained while carefully shaping the petals of her own peony creation. "But when I start working with my hands, making something beautiful, it's like my feelings sort themselves out without me having to think about them directly. The craft work creates space for understanding to happen naturally."

Her words resonated deeply with Marcus's recent experiences, though he had never been able to articulate the phenomenon so clearly. The previous evening's successful recreation of Mrs. Liu's rose technique had indeed provided him with a sense of clarity and calm that had been missing from his daily routine for months. Working with the delicate tissue paper had created a meditative space where the pressures and contradictions of his regular life seemed temporarily suspended, replaced by a focused attention that felt both peaceful and energizing.

Young Sophie, barely eight years old but already remarkably skilled with the paper folding techniques, added her own perspective on the creative process. "My mum says that making beautiful things is like giving presents to the world, even if nobody else ever sees what you've made. She says the world becomes a little bit more beautiful every time someone creates something with love and attention, and that makes everyone's life better somehow."

The philosophical depth of these conversations surprised Marcus, who had grown accustomed to after-school activities that focused primarily on competition, achievement, and social positioning. The craft group seemed to operate according to entirely different values, prioritizing personal expression, mutual support, and the intrinsic satisfaction of creative work over external recognition or comparative success. He began to understand that he had stumbled into a community that might provide exactly the kind of acceptance and encouragement he had been unconsciously seeking.As the craft session progressed, Mrs. Liu introduced more advanced techniques that required increasing levels of precision and patience. Marcus discovered that creating realistic-looking stamens for the peony flowers involved rolling tiny strips of yellow tissue paper around thin wire stems, then carefully fraying the ends to simulate the delicate structures found in actual flowers. The work demanded exactly the kind of meticulous attention to detail that had always made him feel restless during rugby drills, but in this context, the same careful focus felt natural and deeply satisfying.

"In traditional Chinese culture," Mrs. Liu explained while demonstrating how to attach the completed stamens to the flower centers, "we believe that working with our hands in this way connects us to the wisdom of our ancestors. For thousands of years, Chinese women have created beauty through patient craftwork, passing down techniques from mother to daughter like precious gifts. When you learn these skills, you become part of that long chain of creativity and cultural memory."

The idea of connecting with ancient traditions through simple handwork appealed to Marcus in ways he hadn't anticipated. His own family heritage included Chinese ancestry through his mother's lineage, though Dr. Chen had always emphasized academic and professional achievement over cultural practices she viewed as outdated or irrelevant to success in modern New Zealand society. Discovering that his apparently natural aptitude for delicate work might actually represent a connection to generations of skilled craftspeople gave Marcus a sense of belonging that extended far beyond his immediate family or social circle.

Emma, who had been working quietly on an ambitious multi-layered peony design, looked up from her creation with sudden curiosity. "Marcus, do you have any brothers or sisters who might be interested in joining our group? We're always happy to welcome new members, especially ones who take to the work as naturally as you do."

The innocent question created an unexpected moment of discomfort for Marcus, as it reminded him of the elaborate deceptions he had constructed to attend today's session. The reality was that he hadn't told anyone in his family about his participation in the craft group, and he certainly couldn't invite siblings he didn't have to join activities his parents knew nothing about. More troubling still was the growing awareness that his enjoyment of these sessions was creating an increasingly complex double life that would become harder to maintain over time.

"I'm an only child," Marcus replied carefully, hoping to deflect further inquiry without appearing unfriendly. "And my parents are pretty focused on academic work and traditional sports activities. They might not understand why I find this kind of crafting so interesting."

Mrs. Liu paused in her demonstration and regarded Marcus with the kind of penetrating but gentle attention that suggested years of experience reading between the lines of what children said and left unsaid. Her expression conveyed understanding rather than judgment, as if she had encountered similar situations before and recognized the delicate balance between encouraging young people's interests and respecting family dynamics they couldn't control.

"Sometimes parents need time to understand that there are many different ways to develop important life skills," she said diplomatically. "Patience, attention to detail, creative problem-solving, appreciation for beauty – these qualities serve people well in any career or life path they choose to follow. Perhaps someday your parents will see that what you learn here has value beyond just making pretty flowers."

The wisdom in her words provided Marcus with a framework for thinking about his situation that felt both realistic and hopeful. Rather than viewing his participation in the craft group as a rebellion against his parents' values, he could understand it as an exploration of complementary skills that might eventually prove their worth in contexts his mother and father would find acceptable. The patience required for delicate handwork, for example, might indeed transfer to improved performance in academic subjects that demanded sustained concentration. The spatial reasoning involved in visualizing how flat paper could be transformed into three-dimensional flowers might even help with the geometric concepts that had been troubling him in mathematics class.

As the afternoon session drew toward its conclusion, Marcus found himself reluctant to pack up his materials and return to the regular world of homework, family dinner conversations, and preparation for tomorrow's rugby training. The two hours had passed with remarkable speed, leaving him feeling both energized by creative accomplishment and peaceful in a way that was entirely unfamiliar. His completed peony, while not as technically perfect as those created by more experienced group members, possessed a delicate beauty that filled him with quiet pride.

"Would you like to take some extra tissue paper home with you?" Mrs. Liu offered as the group began cleaning up their workspace. "I have plenty of supplies, and practice between sessions will help you develop your skills more quickly. Just remember to work somewhere with good lighting, and don't rush the folding process. The paper will teach you what it wants to become if you listen carefully enough."

Marcus accepted the offered materials with genuine gratitude, though he was already mentally calculating where he might safely practice his new skills without arousing family curiosity. His bedroom seemed like the most obvious choice, but the tissue paper's bright colors and distinctive rustling sounds might attract unwanted attention from parents who were accustomed to monitoring his after-school activities closely. Perhaps he could find opportunities to work in the school library during lunch periods, or even in Hamish McGregor's garden shed if the elderly gardener proved sympathetic to creative pursuits.

The walk home from the library gave Marcus time to process the afternoon's experiences while mentally preparing himself for the inevitable questions about his supposed tutoring activities. The story he had constructed about helping younger students with mathematics homework seemed increasingly flimsy in retrospect, particularly given his own obvious struggles with the subject. He would need to develop more convincing details about his fictional tutees and their specific learning challenges, perhaps even going so far as to research common mathematical difficulties that primary school students experienced.

The late afternoon light was beginning to fade as Marcus approached the familiar streets of Ponsonby, casting long shadows that transformed ordinary suburban landscapes into something more mysterious and beautiful. He found himself noticing details that had previously escaped his attention – the way winter sunlight caught the edges of camellia leaves in front gardens, the delicate patterns created by bare tree branches against the darkening sky, the subtle color variations in weathered wooden fences that lined the narrow streets. The heightened visual awareness seemed to be a direct result of his afternoon spent focused on creating beauty from simple materials, as if the craft work had somehow sharpened his ability to perceive the artistic elements present in everyday surroundings.

As he turned onto his own street, Marcus could see warm lights glowing in the windows of the terrace house that had been his family's home for as long as he could remember. The familiar sight usually filled him with comfortable anticipation of dinner, homework assistance, and the reliable routines that structured his daily life. Tonight, however, he felt a subtle sense of disconnection, as if his experiences at the craft group had created a small but significant gap between his inner reality and the external expectations that awaited him inside those welcoming but somehow limiting walls.

The front door opened before he could reach for his key, revealing his mother still dressed in her hospital scrubs and wearing the expression of mild concern that appeared whenever he arrived home later than expected. Dr. Chen's professional training had made her acutely sensitive to deviations from established patterns, and Marcus realized that his new afternoon activities would require careful management to avoid triggering unwanted parental investigations.

"How did the tutoring session go?" she asked as he stepped into the familiar warmth of the entry hall, her tone carrying genuine interest along with the subtle assessment that was second nature to someone accustomed to evaluating patient responses for signs of underlying problems. "I hope the younger students were appreciative of your help with their mathematics work."

Marcus felt his carefully rehearsed explanations suddenly evaporate under the pressure of direct questioning, leaving him scrambling for details that would sound both convincing and appropriately modest. The transition from the accepting, supportive atmosphere of Mrs. Liu's craft group to the performance-oriented environment of his family home felt jarring in ways he hadn't fully anticipated, highlighting the growing complexity of maintaining separate identities in different contexts.

"It went really well," he managed to reply with what he hoped sounded like appropriate enthusiasm for community service. "The kids I worked with are having trouble with basic geometry concepts, so we spent most of the time going over angle measurements and area calculations. They seemed to understand the material better when I explained it in simpler terms than their regular teacher uses."

The irony of describing geometry instruction to his mother, given his own struggles with exactly those concepts during the morning's mathematics class, wasn't lost on Marcus. He found himself hoping that Dr. Chen wouldn't probe too deeply into the specifics of his teaching methods or ask questions that might reveal the gaps in his own understanding of the subject matter he was supposedly helping others master.

His father emerged from the kitchen at that moment, carrying a cup of tea and wearing the slightly distracted expression that indicated his mind was still partially focused on workplace problems. David Chen's engineering background had given him a natural affinity for mathematical concepts that Marcus had conspicuously failed to inherit, creating another potential source of complications if the conversation moved toward detailed discussion of tutoring techniques or student difficulties.

"Good on you for helping out the younger kids," David said with approval that seemed both genuine and slightly surprised, as if community service wasn't something he had expected his son to pursue independently. "Building teaching skills early will serve you well regardless of what career path you eventually choose. Being able to communicate complex ideas clearly is valuable in any professional context."

The praise felt simultaneously warming and guilt-inducing, representing exactly the kind of parental approval Marcus craved while being based entirely on fictional achievements. He was beginning to understand that maintaining his double life would require not just creative storytelling but also the emotional resilience to accept unearned recognition without letting guilt undermine his confidence or reveal his deceptions through behavioral changes his observant parents might notice.

Dinner conversation that evening revolved around the family's usual topics – his mother's challenging cases at the hospital, his father's current engineering projects, and Marcus's academic progress and extracurricular activities. The familiar rhythm of shared meal discussion felt comforting and slightly suffocating simultaneously, like a well-worn piece of clothing that no longer fit quite as comfortably as it once had. Marcus found himself participating in the conversation with appropriate responses while part of his mind remained focused on memories of tissue paper flowers and the unexpected sense of creative fulfillment he had discovered that afternoon.

"Coach Morrison called earlier to ask about your absence from training today," his father mentioned casually while passing the salad bowl. "I explained about your tutoring commitment, and he seemed impressed by your sense of community responsibility. He did mention that Saturday's match will be particularly important for team rankings, so he's hoping you'll be able to attend the extra practice session they've scheduled for Thursday afternoon."

The news hit Marcus like a physical blow, effectively destroying his hopes of attending Mrs. Liu's second weekly craft session. The scheduling conflict he had been dreading was materializing exactly as he had feared, forcing him to choose between maintaining his rugby commitments and pursuing the creative activities that had brought him such unexpected satisfaction. The unfairness of the situation – being trapped between obligations he had never willingly chosen and interests that felt authentically his own – filled him with a frustration that he struggled to keep hidden from his parents' perceptive attention.

"Of course I'll be there for the extra practice," Marcus replied with as much enthusiasm as he could muster, though he suspected his disappointment was more visible than he intended. "The team's success is definitely more important than my tutoring schedule. I can always help those kids with their mathematics work some other time."

Dr. Chen nodded approvingly at what she interpreted as appropriate priority-setting, while David looked pleased by his son's apparent commitment to team responsibilities. Neither parent seemed to notice the subtle deflation in Marcus's posture or the way his enthusiasm for the conversation had noticeably dimmed following the announcement about Thursday's schedule conflict. The tissue paper that Mrs. Liu had given him remained carefully hidden beneath his textbooks, a small but potent reminder of the creative world he had briefly inhabited and might now be forced to abandon due to scheduling conflicts beyond his control. As he dressed in his school uniform and gathered his materials for the day ahead, Marcus found himself wrestling with a growing sense of resentment toward the well-meaning adults who had structured his life around activities he had never chosen for himself.

The morning sun cast long shadows across the Ponsonby terrace house as twelve-year-old Marcus Chen pressed his nose against the rain-streaked window of his bedroom. Below in the narrow garden, old Hamish McGregor was already at work among the winter vegetables, his weathered hands coaxing life from the Auckland clay despite the persistent drizzle that seemed to define this particular July. Marcus watched the elderly Scotsman's methodical movements with fascination, noting how he treated each plant as if it were a delicate treasure rather than mere greenery.

"Marcus! Breakfast!" His mother's voice carried up the stairs with that familiar note of impatience that had become increasingly common since his father's promotion had begun requiring longer hours at the engineering firm. Dr. Sarah Chen had her own demanding schedule at Auckland Hospital, and the morning routine had become a carefully orchestrated dance of efficiency that left little room for dawdling.

As Marcus reluctantly pulled himself away from the window, his gaze fell upon the stack of tissue paper he'd carefully hidden beneath his school books. The vibrant sheets of crimson, gold, and emerald green seemed to pulse with possibility in the dim morning light. Yesterday, during what was supposed to be a productive study session at the Central Library, he'd discovered something that had ignited a spark of creativity he'd never known existed within him.

It had happened quite by accident. While searching for a book on New Zealand history for his upcoming project, Marcus had wandered into the craft section and stumbled upon an elderly Chinese woman teaching a small group of children how to create elaborate flowers from simple tissue paper. Her fingers moved with an almost magical precision, folding and twisting the delicate material until it bloomed into roses that looked almost real enough to carry fragrance.

"Mei-Mei used to make these for Chinese New Year when she was young girl in Guangzhou," the woman had explained in careful English, her eyes twinkling as she noticed Marcus hovering nearby. "Is very old tradition. Each flower carries wishes for prosperity and happiness."

Something about the gentle concentration required for the craft had called to Marcus in a way that rugby practice and cricket matches never had. When Mrs. Liu – as she'd introduced herself – had invited him to join the group, he'd felt an unfamiliar sense of belonging. His usually clumsy fingers had seemed to understand the delicate work instinctively, and by the end of the session, he'd created a passable lotus blossom that Mrs. Liu had praised with genuine enthusiasm.

"You have gift," she'd told him quietly as the other children packed up their materials. "Most boys, they too rough with paper. But you understand gentleness. This is rare thing."

Now, as Marcus descended the stairs toward the inevitable rush of morning preparations, he clutched the memory of those words like a talisman. The tissue paper upstairs represented something he couldn't quite articulate – a doorway to a part of himself that felt both foreign and completely natural.

The kitchen was already bustling with controlled chaos when he arrived. His mother stood at the counter, efficiently packing lunches while simultaneously reviewing patient notes on her tablet. His father, David, sat hunched over his laptop, a piece of toast growing cold beside him as he frowned at what appeared to be architectural blueprints on the screen.

"Morning, mate," his father mumbled without looking up. "Don't forget you've got rugby training after school today. Coach Morrison says the team needs to work on their scrummage technique before Saturday's match."

Marcus felt his stomach tighten at the reminder. Rugby had been his father's passion during his own school years, and David Chen had naturally assumed his son would share the same enthusiasm for the sport. The reality was far different – Marcus found the aggressive physicality and constant shouting more exhausting than exhilarating, and he'd spent most practices hoping to remain invisible enough to avoid being selected for actual gameplay.

"Actually, Dad, I was thinking maybe I could skip training today. I have that history project due next week, and I really need to get started on the research."

Dr. Chen glanced up from her tablet with a slight frown. "Marcus, you know how we feel about commitment. You made a promise to your team when you joined, and following through on obligations is important for character development."

"Besides," his father added, finally looking away from his screen, "fresh air and physical exercise are exactly what you need. All this indoor time isn't healthy for a boy your age. When I was twelve, I was outside every moment I wasn't in school or sleeping."

Marcus nodded dutifully while internally calculating how he might manage to visit Mrs. Liu's craft session again without arousing suspicion. The group met every Tuesday and Thursday afternoon, which unfortunately coincided perfectly with his rugby commitments. Perhaps he could claim to need extra tutoring in mathematics – his grades in that subject were genuinely struggling enough to make the excuse plausible.

"Hamish seems to be making good progress with the winter plantings," Marcus offered, hoping to change the subject while moving toward a topic that genuinely interested him. "I was watching him work this morning, and he's got those broad beans looking really healthy despite all the rain we've been having."

His mother smiled briefly. "Yes, we're fortunate to have him. Finding someone with his knowledge and dedication isn't easy these days. Most young people aren't interested in that kind of patient, detailed work anymore."

The irony of her words wasn't lost on Marcus, though he kept his expression neutral. If only she knew about the patient, detailed work that had captured his imagination so completely just yesterday. But something told him that tissue paper flowers wouldn't be met with the same approval as successful vegetable gardens or rugby achievements.

As breakfast concluded with the usual flurry of grabbed bags, quick kisses, and reminders about after-school activities, Marcus found himself walking toward Ponsonby Intermediate with a growing sense of internal division. On the surface, he was the dutiful son of successful professional parents, expected to excel academically while maintaining appropriate masculine interests in competitive sports. But beneath that carefully maintained exterior, something new was stirring – a creative impulse that felt both exciting and dangerous.

The school day passed in its typical blur of mathematics struggles, English compositions, and social studies discussions about early Maori settlements. Marcus found his attention wandering repeatedly to memories of Mrs. Liu's gentle instructions and the surprising satisfaction he'd felt when the tissue paper had responded to his careful manipulations. During lunch break, instead of joining his usual group for an improvised game of touch rugby, he retreated to the library and spent the time sketching flower designs in the margins of his notebook.

"Watcha drawing there, Chen?" The voice belonged to Jake Morrison, the rugby coach's son and one of the more vocal members of Marcus's year group. Jake had inherited his father's broad shoulders and aggressive confidence, along with an unfortunate tendency to view any activity that didn't involve physical competition with suspicion.

Marcus quickly closed his notebook, but not before Jake caught a glimpse of the delicate petals he'd been sketching. "Just some diagrams for science class. We're studying plant biology."

"Looked more like girly flower pictures to me," Jake said with a smirk that attracted the attention of several nearby students. "What's next, Chen? Gonna start writing love poems and painting your nails?"

The laughter that followed Jake's comment felt like a physical blow to Marcus's chest. He forced himself to maintain a neutral expression while internally cursing his carelessness. This was exactly the kind of reaction he'd feared, and it confirmed his instinct that his newfound interest needed to remain secret.

"Don't be ridiculous," Marcus replied with what he hoped sounded like casual dismissal. "I was just doodling while thinking about Coach Morrison's scrummage drills. Sometimes drawing helps me visualize the plays better."

Jake seemed satisfied with this explanation, and the conversation moved on to speculation about Saturday's upcoming match against their traditional rivals from Remuera. But Marcus spent the remainder of lunch period acutely aware of how quickly his private world could be exposed and ridiculed.

As the afternoon wore on, Marcus found himself increasingly preoccupied with the collision between his public obligations and private desires. During social studies, while Mr. Patterson droned on about the Treaty of Waitangi, Marcus's mind wandered to the intricate folding techniques Mrs. Liu had demonstrated. He remembered how she had explained that each crease carried meaning, that the ancient art of paper folding was considered a form of meditation in Chinese culture. The idea that creativity could be a spiritual practice was entirely foreign to his experience, yet it resonated with something deep inside him that he couldn't quite name.

When the final bell rang, Marcus gathered his books with unusual reluctance. The prospect of rugby training felt more burdensome than ever, particularly after Jake's earlier comments had made him hyperaware of how his teammates might perceive any deviation from expected masculine behavior. He trudged toward the changing rooms with the grim determination of a soldier heading into an unwelcome battle, already mentally preparing himself for two hours of physical discomfort and forced enthusiasm.

The familiar smell of liniment and sweaty uniforms greeted him as he entered the changing room, where his teammates were already engaged in their pre-training ritual of boastful conversation and aggressive humor. Marcus changed into his practice gear quietly, hoping to avoid drawing attention to himself, but Coach Morrison had other plans.

"Right then, lads!" the coach's voice boomed across the room with characteristic intensity. "Today we're focusing on pack coordination and driving power. Chen, you'll be starting at hooker today. Johnson's still nursing that ankle injury, so I need you to step up and show some leadership in the front row."

Marcus felt his heart sink at this announcement. Playing hooker meant being directly in the middle of every scrum, responsible for accurately throwing the ball into lineouts, and generally being far more involved in the game's physical confrontations than he preferred. It was exactly the kind of prominent role he'd spent months trying to avoid, and now he was being thrust into it at a time when his confidence was already shaken.

"Yes, sir," he managed to reply with what he hoped sounded like appropriate enthusiasm, though several of his teammates exchanged glances that suggested his lack of genuine excitement hadn't gone unnoticed.

The training session that followed was every bit as challenging as Marcus had feared. His lineout throws were consistently inaccurate, sailing either too high for the jumping forwards to reach or falling short of their intended targets. During scrummage practice, he found himself repeatedly overwhelmed by the opposing pack's driving force, unable to maintain the steady platform that his teammates needed. Coach Morrison's increasingly frustrated instructions seemed to make matters worse rather than better, and Marcus could feel his confidence eroding with each failed attempt.

"Chen, you're thinking too much out there!" the coach barked after a particularly disastrous scrum collapse. "Rugby isn't played in your head, son. It's about instinct and aggression. You need to trust your body and stop being so bloody tentative about everything!"

The irony of this advice wasn't lost on Marcus. His recent experience with tissue paper flowers had taught him that some of the most satisfying work required exactly the kind of careful thought and gentle precision that Coach Morrison was telling him to abandon. The contrast between the two activities couldn't have been more stark – one demanded violent forward momentum and dominating physicality, while the other rewarded patient observation and delicate manipulation. He was beginning to understand that his natural temperament was far better suited to the latter, but saying so would have been unthinkable in his current environment.

As practice finally drew to a close, Marcus felt emotionally and physically drained in a way that had nothing to do with healthy exhaustion. He changed back into his school uniform mechanically, barely participating in the post-training analysis that his teammates seemed to relish. When Jake Morrison approached him near the school gates, Marcus braced himself for another uncomfortable conversation.

"Rough session today, mate," Jake said, though his tone carried more curiosity than malice. "You seemed pretty distracted out there. Everything alright at home?"

The question caught Marcus off guard with its unexpected note of genuine concern. Jake might be loud and sometimes insensitive, but he wasn't deliberately cruel, and his father's position as coach meant he had a better understanding than most of the pressures that came with team sports. For a moment, Marcus considered whether he might be able to confide in someone about his conflicted feelings, but the memory of lunchtime's mocking laughter quickly dismissed that possibility.

"Just having trouble concentrating lately," Marcus replied carefully. "Maybe I need to get my eyes checked or something. The ball kept looking blurry during lineout practice."

Jake nodded with apparent understanding. "Yeah, that happened to me last year. Turns out I needed glasses for distance vision. Made a huge difference once I got them sorted. You should definitely talk to your parents about seeing an optometrist."

As they parted ways at the bus stop, Marcus reflected on how easy it had become to construct small deceptions to explain away his struggles. The lie about blurry vision was entirely fabricated, but it provided a convenient medical explanation for his poor performance that didn't require him to examine the deeper truth about his fundamental lack of enthusiasm for rugby. He was becoming skilled at building protective barriers between his inner reality and external expectations, though he wasn't sure whether this was a valuable life skill or a troubling character flaw.

The bus ride home gave him time to decompress from the afternoon's frustrations while planning his next move regarding the tissue paper flowers. Mrs. Liu had mentioned that her craft group met twice weekly, and he was determined to find a way to attend at least one more session. The challenge would be creating a plausible excuse that wouldn't raise suspicions about his true activities. Perhaps he could claim to have joined a study group that met at the library, or volunteer for some kind of community service project that required regular afternoon commitments.

# Chapter 2

The following Tuesday morning arrived with the kind of crisp winter clarity that made Auckland's harbor sparkle like scattered diamonds in the distance. Marcus had spent the better part of three days crafting what he believed to be the perfect excuse for missing rugby training, a story involving voluntary tutoring sessions for younger students who were struggling with their mathematics. The lie sat uncomfortably in his stomach like a cold stone, but his desperate desire to return to Mrs. Liu's craft group had overridden his usual reluctance to deceive his parents.

"That's very commendable, Marcus," his mother had said when he'd presented his fabricated community service commitment over breakfast. "Helping younger students develop confidence in mathematics will be excellent experience for you, and it shows real maturity to recognize that your own understanding improves when you teach others." Dr. Chen had looked genuinely pleased by what she perceived as her son's growing social responsibility, which only intensified Marcus's guilt about the deception.

His father had been equally supportive, though with characteristic pragmatism. "Just make sure you're not taking on so much extra responsibility that your own grades suffer," David had cautioned while reviewing his morning emails.
